ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I think some of the most striking things I learned from this class is not only how humans are similar to other primates, but also how we're very different. It challenged a lot of my assumptions about great apes (particularly chimpanzees), and was really eye-opening. Learning about the underlying reasons (or, possible reasons) for these similarities/differences was also very fun!
general overview of primate intelligence and how it is measured and studied

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Fascinating course. Thorough comments on every essay were extremely helpful. Discussion section posts were not communicated about well.
Incredible class! Loved the lectures, and the writing assignments were interesting.

Strengths: the slideshows were great (I loved that we had access to them on Canvas!). The readings were engaging. I had a lot of fun working on the assignments, because we had a lot of choice in our topics of focus.

Weaknesses: I can't really think of any, to be honest!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I took this class primarily to receive a writing credit and on that end it was very chill and doable. I had no prior interest in primates before this class but I learned a lot about the subject and read a lot of interesting scientific papers and experiments regarding primates.

You don't have to be interested in primatology to take this course. We talk about a lot of social questions such as do primates deserve human rights? Should we do animal testing on primates and if so, how? If you're interested in social questions in the world around us at all, this would be a great course to take. The workload is not a lot at all, and consists of small writing assignments and discussion posts that culminate in an essay at the end is very manageable.
Yes, the material is interesting and very in depth and helpful feedback is provided on the essays.

Absolutely, regardless of major. At the start of every week I looked forward to this class. The topic is absolutely fascinating and Professor Watts is incredibly knowledgeable. If you have any interest in the evolution of intellect, or emotion, or mind of humans and our relatives, please take this class!
